Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Deep Propagating Gravity Wave (DEEPWAVE)
Award.AbstractNarration:
DEEP propagating gravity WAVE (DEEPWAVE) is an interdisciplinary project addressing the propagation and effects of gravity waves (GW) extending from their generation in the troposphere to their breakdown in the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT). The project is designed by experts on the MLT and the lower atmosphere. These research communities have not worked closely together before, but a coupled approach is required to address these dynamics in a comprehensive and consistent manner. GWs strongly influence the dynamics and climate throughout the atmosphere. DEEPWAVE will provide a more complete understanding of GW generation, propagation, breakdown, and energy and momentum transport in the presence of large topography, cyclones, and strong wind shears than has been possible previously.
At the core of the project is a 6-week deployment of the NSF Gulfstream V (GV) research aircraft to Christchurch in June and July 2014. The GV flights will take place over mountain wave locations over and downwind of New Zealand, Tasmania, and islands in the Southern Ocean as well as the southern circumpolar jet that is an additional strong GW source. Recent satellite remote sensing has identified this region as a primary global "hotspot" of GWs reaching high altitudes. Using the GV in situ instruments, dropsondes, and three new airborne remote sensing instruments, nearly the full vertical propagation path of GWs can be observed.
The GV will fly at altitudes from 9-13 km with in situ instruments observing the structure and fluxes of GWs up to ~18 km. On the GV, high-power Rayleigh and Na resonance lidars and an advanced mesospheric temperature mapper (AMTM) will map out GW structures from ~15 to 100 km. These state-of-the-art measurements will be supplemented by ground-based balloon and remote sensing instruments.
This 4-year research program includes DEEPWAVE measurements in 2014, and extensive analysis efforts and associated modeling to quantify the observed dynamics thereafter. All DEEPWAVE data will be made available in a timely fashion. In addition to the investigators supported by this collaborative award, participants supported by NRL as well as international collaborators from New Zealand, Australia, Canada, Germany and the UK will be closely involved in the DEEPWAVE project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Deep Propagating Gravity Wave Experiment (DEEPWAVE) was an international and multi-institutional research program designed to measure and quantify atmospheric gravity waves from their sources in the lower atmosphere to their regions of dissipation at altitudes extending as high as 100 km or above in the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT).  DEEPWAVE was performed on and around the South Island of New Zealand because of its location in a region of strong, diverse gravity wave sources. The Southern Alps are a prolific source of gravity waves excited by airflow over mountains, called mountain waves. Frontal systems, jet streams, and deep convection around New Zealand also excite gravity waves that are representative of these sources around the planet.

 

DEEPWAVE was motivated by 1) the importance of gravity waves in atmospheric circulation and weather and climate prediction, 2) our limited understanding of processes that control their influences throughout the atmosphere, and 3) the potential for new airborne instrumentation to provide new “full-column” measurements able to characterize the gravity wave responses to various sources, especially topography, their spatial scales, propagation to higher altitudes, and consequences in regions of wave breaking and above. 

 

The DEEPWAVE research team included five primary organizations. GATS developed new airborne Rayleigh and sodium resonance lidars for measurements aboard the NSF/NCAR Gulfstream V (GV) research aircraft and operated the lidars for airborne DEEPWAVE measurements of temperatures and sodium densities viewing upward from ~25 to 100 km. Utah State University (USU) developed an airborne Advanced Mesosphere Temperature Mapper (AMTM) for mapping temperature fluctuations above the GV in a horizontal plane at ~85 km. The National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) provided the GV research aircraft that hosted in-situ measurements and the lidars and AMTM, the aircraft crew and support team, and ground-based radiosonde and boundary layer radar measurement systems and their operators. The German Aerospace Center (DLR) contributed their Falcon research aircraft, a ground-based Rayleigh lidar, and a radiosonde system. Additionally, the Naval Research Laboratory contributed personnel and both mesoscale and global forecasting capabilities to aid flight planning. Other ground-based instrumentation in New Zealand was provided by the University of Washington, Boston University, and (USU), and Australian colleagues installed a radar and lidar on Tasmania to support DEEPWAVE flights over the Southern Ocean.

 

The GV and Falcon aircraft flew 26 and 13 research flights, respectively, from early June to late July 2014, and ground-based instruments began operations several weeks before the first flights and continued for a number of months thereafter. Altogether, over 100 people participated in DEEPWAVE flight forecasting, mission planning, support operations, ground-based and airborne measurements, reporting, and education and public outreach.

 

DEEPWAVE research efforts have led to about 40 scientific papers and very many conference presentations to date. They have also contributed major advances in our understanding of these important gravity wave dynamics and effects that we expect will contribute to improved weather and climate prediction in the future.
